Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: Amember of the parish has requested a meeting with the nun to discuss a personal crisis of faith.
Story: I sat at the edge of my narrow bed, the old family photo in my hand, the rosary in the other. My mother’s voice echoed in my mind, reminding me how important it was to lead the family ceremony this year, to honor our ancestors and keep our traditions alive. I could see her hopeful eyes, the pride she would feel if I stood at the front, guiding prayers and rituals as my father once did. Yet, the convent bell chimed softly, a reminder of my other life. Sister Agnes had just told me that Mrs. Ramirez, a devoted parishioner, was waiting for me in the chapel, desperate to talk about her crisis of faith. As a nun, I was expected to be present, to listen, to offer spiritual guidance and comfort. My heart pulled in two directions—toward my family’s expectations and the needs of my spiritual community. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing on my chest, the fear of disappointing those I loved, and the guilt of neglecting my calling. I closed my eyes, torn, unsure which path to take.
